article.title: Quenched dynamics of classical isolated systems: the spherical spin model with two-body random interactions or the Neumann integrable model

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 (a) illustrate about the equilibrium Lagrange multiplier at finite N?
choices: It is always smaller than the maximum eigenvalue of the interaction matrix.
It converges to the paramagnetic curve at low temperatures, regardless of system size.
It collapses onto the paramagnetic curve at high temperatures, irrespective of system size.
It shows a non-monotonic trend with system size at all temperatures.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the system size scaling of the Lagrange multiplier in the condensed phase, shown in Figure 1 (b), reveal?
choices: The difference between the Lagrange multiplier and the maximum eigenvalue of the interaction matrix increases linearly with 1/N.
The dashed lines, representing T/(Nqin), accurately capture the behavior of the system for all temperatures below the transition.
For temperatures significantly below the transition, the finite size data deviate from the infinite size results for all system sizes analyzed.
The system size scaling is independent of the particular realization of disorder chosen for each size.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from Figure 2 (a) concerning the equilibrium self-overlap (qin) at finite N?
choices: It converges to the N → ∞ predictions as the system size increases.
It exhibits a strong dependence on the specific realization of disorder used for each size.
It remains constant below the transition temperature, regardless of system size.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation (167) demonstrate about the potential energy of the highest mode (pot\nN) in equilibrium?
choices: It diverges with increasing system size.
It is inconsistent with the equipartition theorem.
It assumes the correct value consistent with the equipartition theorem if s2\nN eq = q(N)\nin N.
It is independent of the equilibrium Lagrange multiplier.
